passage_text: Visitors to Arima Onsen can enjoy hot spring bathing at two public bath houses or at the town's many ryokan. Several ryokan open their baths also to non-staying visitors during the day. The admission fee for a daytrip visit to a bath typically ranges between 500 and 2500 yen.

Arima Onsen (L n) is a famous hot spring town within the city limits of Kobe, but on the opposite side of Mount Rokko from the city center. The town lies in a natural mountain setting, yet is close enough for Kobe and Osaka residents as an easy and popular day trip or weekend getaway.

Arima-onsen Hot Spring is one of the oldest springs in Japan and is said to have been opened since the Buddhist monks built a sanitarium in the 8th century. The Arima-onsen is very popular as it is often referred to as the back parlor of Keihanshin (Kyoto, Osaka, and Kobe).

Arima Onsen (有馬温泉) [1] is a hot spring town just north of Kobe, Japan. Arima Onsen is one of Japan's Three Old Hot Springs, with a recorded history going back to the Nihon Shoki, published in 631. The waters of Arima come in two flavors: the Gold Spring (金泉 Kinsen) is yellow-brown thanks to iron and salt, while the Silver Spring (銀泉 Ginsen) is colorless but mildly radioactive.

Arima Onsen. Arima Onsen is one of the oldest hot spring resorts in Japan, along with Shirahama Onsen in Wakayama Prefecture and Dogo Onsen on Shikoku Island. “Arima Onsen near my hometown of Kobe is famous for its special gold and silver' spa waters.
